_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The industry ALBERTO CULVER (PR) INC is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental
safety. It is their policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent potential releases of regulated 
substances. The industry' primary activities are Health and Beauty products. The regulated process involve
the manufacture of hair mousses and feminine deodorant spray. Isobutane and Dymel are used as 
dispersants for the products. 

The industry has two regulated substances, both flammables: A-31 Isobutane (Propane, 2 methyl) and Dymel
(mixture of isobutane, propane and difluoroethane). They also have LPG cylinders. The regulated substances
are flammables used in the process. The LPG is used to fuel a flare control system for the process. There 
are two storage tanks of 18,000 gallons each to store Isobutane and Dymel. Only one tank is used at a time 
for the process. A maximum of 6-239 lbs of LPG cylinders are stored in the facility, with one LPG cylinder
in line with the flare's pilot flame. In February 2003, the propellant used in the manufacture (A-46, a mixture 
of Isobutane and Propane) was changed to Dymel. Isobutane is used for the manufacture of FDS, feminine
deodorant spray.

Results of the Offsite consequence analysis are included as part of the requirements of this form. The facility
is subject to OSHA PSM and so it qualifies for Program 3 processes It is also in compliance with OSHA PSM. 
Rule. Although the propellants were changed and the results for the scenarios were the same as before, the 
PHA and all the PHA requisites were updated. Back-up systems were revised and some additional ones 
(portable OVA analyzer) were recommended, operating procedures were updated, training was updated, 
and maintenance procedures were revised.

There has not been any accidental release in the last five years previous to the submission of this RMP that
has resulted in serious onsite or offsite impacts.

The facility has an Emergency Action Plan. It is in compliance wi

th EPCRA requirements and so the SERC,
the LEPC and the local Fire Department have information on the hazardous substance stored and used and
included this information in the State Emergency Response Plan. An Emergency Response Plan was 
prepared for the facility to comply with Program 3 processes and will be fully implemented in the next months.
Training has been updated and drills with the local Fire Department will be coordinated.

Changes have been planned to improve safety. Some of these are: the use of a portable OVA analyzer in 
daily inspections made to transfer lines and during loading/unloading of propellants, update training program
and schedule, coordinate drills with local Fire Department and update operating procedures.
